item.title: H.R. 2817, National Historic Preservation Amendments Act

item.fullName: Rep. Carney, John C., Jr. [D-DE-At Large]

latestAction.text: Placed on the Union Calendar, Calendar No. 576.

item.titleType: Short Titles as Reported to House
item.title: National Historic Preservation Amendments Act
National Historic Preservation Amendments Act of 2015
To amend title 54, United States Code, to extend the authorization of appropriations for the Historic Preservation Fund.

bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. TURNER:H.R. 2817.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8; and Article IV, Section 3, Clause 2of the Constitution of the United States of America____________________[Page H4492]
bill.title: National Historic Preservation Amendments Act

item.name: Introduced in House
item.text:
National Historic Preservation Amendments Act of 2015

This bill extends the Historic Preservation Fund through FY2025.

item.name: Reported to House with amendment(s)
item.text:
National Historic Preservation Amendments Act

(Sec. 2) This bill extends the Historic Preservation Fund through FY2023.

The Department of the Interior may accept nominations by federal agencies for the inclusion of properties on the National Register of Historic Places only in accordance with the nomination requirements described by this bill.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
